title: Great Sand Dunes National Park & Preserve: Basic Information
body: Explore This Park    Plan Your Visit     Basic Information             Basic Information                   Experience the Dunes               Camping and Lodging               Splash in Medano Creek               Explore Great Sand Dunes National Preserve               Photos and Multimedia               Nature and Science                2016 Visitor Guide The 2016 Visitor Guide (pdf, 2 MB) provides the best planning maps and overview of the park and preserve.                         Things to Do           Camping and Lodging           Medano Creek  Conditions and Forecast           Weather/Webcam             Pets           Permits (Weddings, Filming, Research)            NPS/Patrick Myers  Welcome to Great Sand Dunes!   Exploring Dunes, Grasslands, Forests, Lakes, and Alpine Peaks Many visitors are surprised at the huge size and diversity of this park, and wish they had planned more time. Plan to experience at least two or three ecosystems during your stay to have the most fulfilling visit. Discover Things to Do and how to experience them. View and print a Map of Permitted Pet Areas. Spending the Night Find detailed information on camping and lodging options in and near the park, or link to make reservations at Pñon Flats Campground in the national park. Plan ahead to experience the night at Great Sand Dunes. Be Prepared Great Sand Dunes is a high elevation park in the Rocky Mountains, ranging from 7515 ft (2308m) to 13,604 ft (4146m). Storms can arise quickly, bringing cold, wet conditions any time of year. Be prepared for a wide variety of conditions during your visit. Check the weather page for the best online forecast and detailed information, and view the park webcam for current conditions. Summer high temperatures average 80 F, with lows in the 40s F. However, sand surface temperatures often reach 150 F in the afternoon before thunderstorms develop. In summer, plan your dunes time for early morning or evening to avoid burned feet, heat exhaustion, or lightning strikes. Summer afternoons are a great time to hike or 4WD into mountain areas of the park, as well as splash in nearby Zapata Falls. Fall conditions are usually excellent, with sunny, calm days in the 60s-70s F and chilly nights. Winter days are generally sunny and cold with highs in the teens - 20s F. The sand may feel warm in the intense alpine sun, but be prepared for blizzards anytime and subzero temperatures at night. Spring can mean anything from blizzards to warm swimsuit weather - sometimes in one day! March and April are the two swowiest months in Colorado, but there are also warm days. Spring is the windy season throughout the western United States, and Great Sand Dunes may also be windy during a spring visit. Afternoons are usually the windiest part of the day; plan to hike on the dunes in morning. Late spring usually brings pleasant temperatures along with the peak flow of Medano Creek in late May.           Physical Address           Visitor Center 11999 State Highway 150  Mosca, CO 81146                 Directions         To access the main park area, including the Dunes Parking Lot, Visitor Center, and Pinyon Flats Campground, take US 160 to CO 150 from the south, or CO 17 to Lane 6 to CO 150 from the west. The national park is at the north end of CO 150.  Directions Details           Operating Hours & Seasons         Great Sand Dunes National Park and Preserve Always open 24/7 all year   Standard Hours    Sunday: Open 24 hours   Monday: Open 24 hours   Tuesday: Open 24 hours   Wednesday: Open 24 hours   Thursday: Open 24 hours   Friday: Open 24 hours   Saturday: Open 24 hours             Weather           Temperatures are relatively cool all year, thanks to the park and preserve's high elevation. Conditions are most often calm, but winds can arise, especially in spring and during storm fronts.  Daytime temperatures feel warmer here year round due to intense high-altitude sunlight, and a scorching mid-day summer sand surface. Plan to explore the dunes morning or evening during summer. Nights are cool in summer, and frigid in winter. Visit the Great Sand Dunes website for the most accurate weather forecasts.         Fees & Passes     Entrance Fees:   Non-Commercial Vehicle and Occupants - $15.00 Passenger vehicle with all occupants; fee valid for 7 days.   Oversized Vehicle, 15+ passengers, age 16+ - $7.00 Per passenger, 16 years and older in oversized vehicle, including 15 passenger vans, small buses, etc. Valid for 7 days. Passengers under 16 are free.   Motorcycle and Riders - $10.00 One motorcycle and all its riders; valid for 7 days.   Entrance Passes:   Great Sand Dunes Annual Family Pass - $30.00 Covers one family's entrance for 12 months from time of purchase. Valid for two adults with signatures plus others in vehicle.         Visitor Centers       Great Sand Dunes Visitor Center The Visitor Center features: -20-minute movie about the park - Interactive exhibits for all ages - Park store with wide selection of books, postcards, magnets, T-Shirts, posters, toys, games, and more - Exhibit area of fine art paintings and photography - First Aid Room - Back porch with viewing scope - Restrooms and drinking water - Simple snacks - Firewood for sale (when campground concessioner is not open) - Rangers to answer questions and help you plan your visit
